B00005QY5Y|4.0|Oops. After struggling with Adams' previous album, Heartbreaker, and eventually giving up on it, I presumed that his solo career was going to hold little interest for me. Well, based on Gold, I'm going to have to re-evaluate that presumption. Where Heartbreaker was lackluster and dull, Gold is ambitious and intriguing. Heartbreaker lulled me to sleep with an endless series of lullaby-like dirges, but this new collection sets the pace with a bit more energy, resulting in an album that is downright stimulating, or at least interesting. The full collection features a rather generous twenty-one songs, five of which appear on a second disk entitled `Side 4'.<br /><br />Most of the songs here are chord-driven, mid-tempo rockers with appealing melodies. The overall feel remains earthy, but Adams isn't afraid to use flourishes as required, so arrangements are sometimes ornamental, using orchestration and choruses to full effect. It's no wonder that Elton John took a liking to Adams, since the arrangements here suggest those found on Tumbleweed Connection and his own first album. At other times, Adam sounds like he could have been writing for the 1974-era Faces; a song like \\"Rescue Blues\\" could have been an outtake from the \\"Ooh La La\\" sessions. At first, \\"New York\\" sounds like a love letter to Manhattan, but it is really directed to a female resident. In retrospect, the video that accompanied this track is relatively creepy, since it featured Adams singing with the World Trade Center as his backdrop, filmed just days before 9/11.<br /><br />As the disk progresses, the songs build upon one another. \\"Firecracker\\" is a pleasant, rootsy, mid-tempo rocker that is typical of the album, as is \\"Answering Bell, which also features a fine melody but adds a nice organ break for flavor. The best songs arrive mid-disk, though, with the melancholy reflection of<br /><br />\\"Somehow, Someday\\" surpassed only by the gorgeously wrought melody of \\"When the Stars Go Blue,\\" a song that might qualify as Adams' best to date. \\"Sylvia Plath\\" could have been equally intriguing, but a line like \\"Maybe she'd give me a bath\\" wrecks the mood, since it strikes me as a rather obvious and artless reach for a rhyme with the subject's name. The overall mood here is both sad and beautiful, although things start to slack off towards disk's end. The bonus tracks add some fun to the equation, and although Gold still has its share of filler, there is plenty here to recommend it.<br /><br />Afternote - In the wake of Gold, Adams seemed poised to hit a home run with his next record. Instead, he opted to bunt, releasing a collection of uneven demo tracks. Far be it from me to give career advice, though. For me, the bottom line is that there is one great Ryan Adams solo record, and this is it.  A-  Tom Ryanalify as Adams' best to date. \\"Sylvia Plath\\" could have been equally intriguing, but a line like \\"Maybe she'd give me a bath\\" wrecks the mood, since it strikes me as a rather obvious and artless reach for a rhyme with the subject's name. The overall mood here is both sad and beautiful, although things start to slack off towards disk's end. The bonus tracks add some fun to the equation, and although Gold still has its share of filler, there is plenty here to recommend it.  <br /> <br />Afternote - In the wake of Gold, Adams seemed poised to hit a home run with his next record. Instead, he opted to bunt, releasing a collection of uneven demo tracks. Far be it from me to give career advice, though. For me, the bottom line is that there is one great Ryan Adams solo record, and this is it.     A-    Tom Ryan

3257229534|5.0|Winner of the Boston Review's Fisk Fiction Prize, this thematically complex story is written in clear, simple, lucid prose. It is a straightforward telling of an encounter that was to mark fifteen year old Michael Berg for life. The book, written as if it were a memoir, is divided into three parts. The first part of the book deals with that encounter.<br /><br />While on his way home from school one day in post-war Germany, Michael becomes ill. He is aided by a beautiful and buxom, thirty six year old blonde named Hanna Schmitz. When he recovers from his illness, he goes to Frau Schmitz's home to thank her and eventually finds himself seduced by her and engaged in a sexual encounter. They become lovers for a period of time, and a component of their relationship was that Michael would read aloud to her. Michael romanticizes their affair, which is a cornerstone of his young life. They even go away on a trip together. Then, one day, as suddenly as she appeared in his life, she disappears, having inexplicably moved with no forwarding address.<br /><br />The second part of the book deals with Michael's chance encounter with Hanna again. He is now a law student in a seminar that is focused on Germany's Nazi past and the related war trials. The students are young and eager to condemn all who, after the end of the war, had tolerated the Nazis in their midst. Even Michael's parents do not escape his personal condemnation. The seminar is to be an exploration of the collective guilt of the German people, and Michael embraces the opportunity, as do others of his generation, to philosophically condemn the older generation for having sat silently by. Then, he is assigned to take notes on a trial of some camp guards.<br /><br />To his total amazement, one of the accused is Hanna, his Hanna. He stoically remains throughout the trial, realizing as he hears the evidence that she is refusing to divulge the one piece of evidence that could possibly absolve her or, at least, mitigate her complicity in the crimes with which she is charged. It is as if she considers her secret, that of her inability to read and write, more shameful than that of which she is accused. Yet, Michael, too, remains mute on the fact that would throw her legal, if not her moral, guilt into question. Consequently, Hanna finds herself bearing the legal guilt of all those involved in the crime of which she is accused and is condemned accordingly.<br /><br />The third part of the book is really the way Michael deals with having found Hanna, again. He removes himself from further demonstration and discussion on the issue of Germany's Nazi past. It affects his decisions as to his career in the law, eventually choosing a legal career that is isolating. He marries and has a child but finds that he cannot be free of Hanna. He cannot be free of the pain of having loved Hanna. It is as if Hanna has marked him for life. He divorces and never remarries. It is as if he cannot love another, as he loved Hanna. Michael then reaches out to Hanna in prison, indirectly, through the secret they share of what she seems to be most ashamed. Yet, he carefully never personalizes the contact. The end, when it comes, is almost anti-climatic.<br /><br />The relationship between Michael and Hanna really seems to be analogous to the relationship between the generations of Germans in post-war Germany. The affair between Michael and Hanna is representational of the affair that Germany had with the Nazi movement. The eroticism of the book is a necessary component for the collective guilt and shame that the Germans bear for the Holocaust, as well as for the moral divide that seemingly exists between the generations. Yet, the book also shows that such is not always a black and white issue, that there are sometimes gray areas when one discusses one's actions in the context of the forces of good and evil. There is also the issue of legal and moral responsibility. One would think that the two are synonymous, butthey are not always so. It also philosophizes on the ability to love another/a nation who/that was complicit in war crimes. This is the German text edition of \\"The Reader\\", an insightful, allegorical book that defies categorizing. It is also a book that is a wonderful selection for a reading circle, as it has a wealth of issues that are ripe for discussion. This is simply a superlative book. Bravo!they are not always so. It also philosophizes on the ability to love another/a nation who/that was complicit in war crimes. This is the German text edition of \\"The Reader\\", an insightful, allegorical book that defies categorizing. It is also a book that is a wonderful selection for a reading circle, as it has a wealth of issues that are ripe for discussion. This is simply a superlative book. Bravo!

It's not just that they are more progressive than the other songs.  It's that DT is clearly more excited and interested in performing this type of music.  That's why the other songs sound flat. <br /> <br />I still don't know what's going on with Petrucci.  Anyone that heard his live album with Jordan Rudess or either of the Liquid Tension Experiment albums knows that John can weave dazzling shredding pyrotechnics with melody at the highest level. B000000W5N|5.0|Sticky Fingers(1971). The Rolling Stones' Eleventh Studio Album.<br /><br />In 1971, The Rolling Stones were fresh off the sucess of Let It Bleed, but were slowly succumbing to various drug addictions and relationship problems. Sticky Fingers turns out to be one of The Stones' most personal and darkest releases, yet it still rocks as hard as anything before it. Although guitarist Mick Taylor was used sparingly on Let It Bleed, on Sticky Fingers he took a lead role in the production of the album. Pieced together from many hard-labored outtakes and full-length tracks, Sticky Fingers took an unusually long time to record, but upon its release it was a worldwide smash hit. Although \\"Brown Sugar\\" and \\"Wild Horses\\" were the only hits off Sticky Fingers, it is widely regarded as The Rolling Stones' greatest achievement, an album where every song is just as important as its singles. What did I think of Sticky Fingers? Read on to find out.<br /><br />Track Ratings-<br /><br />BROWN SUGAR - The Rolling Stones classic opener \\"Brown Sugar\\" deals explicitly with interracial sex, losing your virginity, and even drug use. Did that stop it from becoming a huge hit? No way. \\"Brown Sugar\\" happens to be The Rolling Stones' finest hit, sporting a truly classic Keith Richards' riff and Mick Jaggers' vocals at their most cocky and energetic. Perfect way to start an album!<br /><br />SWAY - The Rolling Stones finest moment, \\"Sway\\" is a heavy, emotional rocker that never fails to impress. A fine work of emotional guitar and vocal harmonies, \\"Sway\\" builds up to a frantic guitar solo, which perfectly caps off The Rolling Stones greatest achievement. Imagine The Rolling Stones with Joe Perry, and you have an idea of what it might sound like. Perfect.<br /><br />WILD HORSES - The Rolling Stones first serious country song, \\"Wild Horses\\" stands as a heart-tugging emotional masterpiece. Mick Jagger's heartbroken vocals blend seamlessly with a tearful acoustic guitar melody to create an emotional tour-de-force. A truly beautiful and amazing track.<br /><br />CAN'T YOU HEAR ME KNOCKING - The Rolling Stones keep the great tracks coming, and next is \\"Can't You Hear Me Knocking\\". A hard rocking, in-your-face song blasts out of your stereo, with Jagger's seething vocals and Richard's punchy electric riff, before the track transforms into a funky jam session. Can you believe it? Another perfect track.<br /><br />YOU GOTTA MOVE - Sticky Fingers' weakest track, \\"You Gotta Move\\" is a amusing and brief country tune. Much like most of The Rolling Stones country material, \\"You Gotta Move\\" finds Jagger and Richards overexaggerating country cliches with funny results. Doesn't really take away from the album - I enjoyed it!<br /><br />BITCH - The Rolling Stones mean-spirited rocker \\"Bitch\\" is another fabulous effort, mixing in Mick Jagger's seething and pouting singing with a brazen mix of hard rock guitar and trumpets. A fun rocker that doesn't fail to please.<br /><br />I GOT THE BLUES - The Rolling Stones song that inspired Bon Jovi to be a musician, \\"I Got The Blues\\" is The Rolling Stones' finest take on pure blues. Jaggers' brooding blues vocals bond with Keith Richards and Mick Taylor's searing blues guitar work to create a masterful blues-rock track.<br /><br />SISTER MORPHINE - The Rolling Stones' most personal and revealing track, \\"Sister Morphine\\" was written by Marianne Faithfull, Mick Jagger's girlfriend. A truthful and depressing ballad about the dangers of drug abuse, \\"Sister Morphine\\" turns out to be The Rolling Stones most revealing moment of their career. Truly beautiful in an offhand way.<br /><br />DEAD FLOWERS - The Rolling Stones' brighten up for \\"Dead Flowers\\", and although the lyrics are still depressing and desolate, The Stones play a serious, yet funky little rocker. The Rolling Stones are excellent at dark rockers, and this is no exception. It reminds me a little of \\"Stupid Girl\\".<br /><br />MOONLIGHT MILE - A dark stirring ballad to close the album, \\"Moonlight Mile\\" finds Mick Jagger soulfully letting his sorrows out behind a string arrangement and a crying acoustic guitar. Sticky Fingers couldn't have ended any better.<br /><br />Sticky Fingers, without a doubt, is a classic rock masterpiece. While I've always liked The Rolling Stones, Sticky Fingers introduced me to a new side of them, a darker side that faces up more to the realities of life than the happy-go-lucky rock of \\"Satisfaction\\" or \\"It's Only Rock And Roll.\\" Sticky Fingers truly is a perfect album, where each song blends into the next, and there is never a dull moment, something many Rolling Stones albums suffer from. While the Rolling Stones had many other good albums (Aftermath, Beggar's Banquet), they could never quite equal Sticky Fingers, and they probably never will.<br /><br />HIGHLY RECOMMENDED FOR FANS OF CLASSIC ROCK AND THE ROLLING STONES! THEIR FINEST MOMENT, AND SOMETHING YOU SHOULDN'T MISS!<br /><br />Also Recommended-<br /><br />Aftermath - The Rolling Stones<br /><br />The White Album - The Beatles<br /><br />The Who By Numbers - The Who<br /><br />Thanks For Readingng ballad to close the album, \\"Moonlight Mile\\" finds Mick Jagger soulfully letting his sorrows out behind a string arrangement and a crying acoustic guitar. Sticky Fingers couldn't have ended any better. <br /> <br />Sticky Fingers, without a doubt, is a classic rock masterpiece. While I've always liked The Rolling Stones, Sticky Fingers introduced me to a new side of them, a darker side that faces up more to the realities of life than the happy-go-lucky rock of \\"Satisfaction\\" or \\"It's Only Rock And Roll.\\" Sticky Fingers truly is a perfect album, where each song blends into the next, and there is never a dull moment, something many Rolling Stones albums suffer from. While the Rolling Stones had many other good albums (Aftermath, Beggar's Banquet), they could never quite equal Sticky Fingers, and they probably never will. <br /> <br />HIGHLY RECOMMENDED FOR FANS OF CLASSIC ROCK AND THE ROLLING STONES! THEIR FINEST MOMENT, AND SOMETHING YOU SHOULDN'T MISS! <br /> <br />Also Recommended- <br /> <br />Aftermath - The Rolling Stones <br />The White Album - The Beatles <br />The Who By Numbers - The Who <br /> <br />Thanks For Reading <br /> <br />

B0000931QA|5.0|I was first introduced to Operation : Mindcrime following its release.  My friend let me borrow his copy, and advised me to \\"listen to it with the lights off, it will scare the hell out of you\\".  So I did.<br /><br />To this day, whenever I recommend this album to someone, that is the same advice that I give to them, as his suggestion holds true.  This is an album that is far more than just background noise; it needs to be listened to in order to be not just appreciated, but truly absorbed.<br /><br />In this reviewer's opinion, this is the best concept album ever recorded.  Ever.  In a word, it's a masterpiece.  The album's dark themes, piercing musicianship, and brilliant lyrical work make this album stand out in a way that no other album from the time it was released does.<br /><br />The story revolves around Nikki, a young man who was born to lose, being recruited by the evil Dr. X to execute a series of religious and political assassinations.  Nikki falls in love with a young nun named Mary, who hails from a similar background.  The story unfold from there, song for song.  The story is interesting, complex, and full of enough intrigue (not to mention the music is fantastic) to keep the listener hanging on every lyric until the final note fades.<br /><br />I would go as far as to label the latter half of the album (from \\"Electric Requiem\\" to \\"Eyes of a Stranger\\") as nothing less than a tour de force.  Presented with a relentless machine-gun pace, its fluidity keeps the story flowing perfectly.  It's song-to-song succession is not unlike the latter half of the Beatles' Abbey Road, in regards to its flow.  Yes, really.  It's that good.<br /><br />In the 80s, Queensryche had the misfortune (or good fortune, depending on who you ask) of being lumped into categories with hair metal acts that were popular at the time this record was released, and this album may never receive the appreciation that it truly deserves because of that.  If so, that is truly a shame, because this is an album that belongs in every music lover's collection.  I wish I could give it more than five stars.  This album is as close to perfect as it gets.lbum that belongs in every music lover's collection.   I wish I could give it more than five stars.   This album is as close to perfect as it gets.

B0008JIJ2E|5.0|All hail the Crane Kick, liberator of useless wimps over bullies, redeemer of lost causes, winner of Elisabeth Shue's heart.  <br />  <br />The arms-raised-left-knee-arched-jump-kick-flashbulb-combo at the climax of 'The Karate Kid' is one of cinema's sterling images, along with Arnie killing the Predator at the end of Predator, when optimus Prime dies and 1 hour, 12 mins, 37 secs into the Crying Game. <br />  <br />Strike the pose anywhere in the film-watching world and you'll get a laugh or nod of affirmation, the auto-acknowledgment triggered by a giddy memory of the underdog movie that has the tendency to be trivialised and dismissed. Never mind the film earned more than $90 million at the box office and was followed by three (shoddy) sequels, a video game and a Saturday-morning cartoon.  <br />  <br />Maybe the uneasiness in fully embracing 'The Karate Kid' comes from the fact that it emerged in 1980s' synth-rock cheesiness, and its broad, bold outlines overshadow its quiet tenderness. Its over-the-top fight scenes and blatant emotional manipulation have a way of tricking your brain into thinking it was a trifle you enjoyed at the time but has no persevering significance. Pop it into the DVD player and the film will prove otherwise.  <br />  <br />'The Karate Kid' channels an ancient power, its called nostalgia, with the resonance of a folk tale and the beauty of a daydream. It's inspirational without being condescending. Truthful but not heavy handed.  <br />  <br />The story is of Daniel (Ralph Macchio), a weakling boy who is forced to move across the country with his mother, only to be bullied by a gang of karate thugs (Heil Sensie Kreese!). At rock bottom, Daniel finds himself and escapes a personal hell through the help of a supportive girlfriend, Ali (Elisabeth Shue) and a wise mentor, Miyagi (Noriyuki \\"Pat\\" Morita). Daniel, referred to as \\"Daniel-san\\" by Miyagi, trains for a karate tournament in which he will face his cruel tormenter, Johnny (William Zabka), who also happens to be Ali's controlling ex.  <br />  <br />For such a predictable story, 'The Karate Kid' yields surprises on repeat viewings. It raises the eyebrows to re-experience Miyagi's distant, rough-English wisdom, which rings true with a red-letter import. It gladdens the heart to treasure the film's unorthodox tendency to dally in small, quiet texture. And most invigorating is the acting, which is uniformly superb. Director John G. Avildsen (\\"Rocky\\") has a way of extracting naturalistic performances, fleshed out with tiny, significant details.  <br />  <br />The sagely Morita is the standout, in the role that would define him, and the first American-born Asian to be nominated for a best-supporting actor Oscar.  <br />  <br />Macchio, 22 at the time, is 'convincing' as a spindly 16-year-old, not only for his boyish looks, but also his studied demeanor, teeming with adolescent testoteroned uncertainty.  <br />  <br />Both actors completely sold themselves into roles, at the price of being forever typecast, with the reward of crafting everlasting characters that become ingrained into society. If there's any doubt about what the parts continue to mean to Morita and Macchio, take a stroll to 8225 W. Sunset Blvd. in West Hollywood, Calif., where you'll find the restaurant Morita started, called Miyagi's. And look up Macchio's biography, where you'll see his son is named Daniel.  <br />  <br />The father-son rapport between the Miyagi and Daniel is palpable, as Miyagi, the Okinawan handyman (or ex-Japanese POW)in Daniel's apartment complex, takes him under his wing. Johnny, jealous of Ali's romantic interest, bitch slaps Daniel daily. The boys' first fight, at a beach in front of Daniel's new friends, ends so badly that Daniel is mockingly named \\"The Karate Kid.\\"  <br />  <br />Miyagi rescues Daniel from a Halloween-night beating by Johnny's skeleton-suited Cobra Kais, and makes a deal with the bullies' brutish Sensei that the boys are not allowed to fightDaniel until he's finished training. Then commences Daniel's learning, which begins with the iconic 'wax on, wax HOFF' demands.  <br />  <br />Daniel bristles at what appears to be busywork, as he waxes Miyagi's cars and paints his fences. Just as the boy is about to quit in frustration, Miyagi shows Daniel that the chores have been teaching him motor skills useful for karate blocks. Daniel wants to learn to punch, but that must come later.  <br />  <br />First learn stand, then learn fly. Nature rule, Daniel-san, not mine.  <br />  <br />Miyagi's lessons of balance, study and nonviolence are a harsh contrast to those of the Cobra Kai, in which students chant, \\"Strike first, strike hard, no mercy!\\" 'Heil Sensie Kreese!'  <br />  <br />Daniel eventually finds that he must learn to fight so he doesn't have to fight. And that self-discipline and dedication are musts.  <br />  <br />Daniel-san, must talk. Man walk on road. Walk left side, safe. Walk right side, safe. Walk down middle, sooner or later, get knocked down. Same here. You karate do yes or karate do no. You karate do guess so.  <br />  <br />There's no doubt that this is a melodrama. There's a villain, a damsel and a hero, although often in this movie the hero is more of a damsel and the damsel more of a hero. By movie's end we're assured that Daniel-san's combat skills are superior to those of Johnny, but not at all that he could take firebrand Ali, who unlike her scrawny new boyfriend, never runs from the big bully, and even pops Johnny with a loud slap.  <br />  <br />Looming is the crowd-pleasing showdown with Johnny. The story redeems its obviousness with the glowing message that it's insignificant whether Daniel wins the tournament. What matters is he's found the courage to enter the fray, and the drive to work hard and long enough to deserve to win. Daniel has learned to stand. The Crane Kick is just a bonus.

B000001G5H|5.0|In reading these various reviews, let's say that everyone has their own opinion.  However, wheter one sees Pollini's Chopin as cold and indifferent (someone calls him a \\"calculator\\") or as one of the greats of this generation, I simply invite you to listen.  I will give you a specific, towards the end of the powerful Etude nos 12 op.10, starting at the 2'12\\" mark, listen to the way Pollini handles the left hand arpeggios, the accompaniment.  With anyone else, this is just that, but with Pollini, this becomes- for me- a meditative, masterpiece of stillness, juxtaposed with the thunder that flashes at at 2'30\\".  No one else plays it like this.      Another aspect of Pollini's unique style of interpretation can be heard in the nos7 op.25, the greatest of the Etudes.  This is usually played as an overtly Romantic, love-sick tune, done to the point of smaltz.  Pollini plays the notes as Chopin writes them.  No more, no less.      Is Romantic music such as Chopin's to be interpreted from performer to performer, from generation to generation as the reviewer below says?  I think not.  If Chopin wanted something to be played with extra sadness or expression, he would have indicated so.  George Sand documentated famously how Frederick would tear his hair out getting a single bar of music just right, taking days behind a closed door.  A single bar!!  The great composers were aboslutely meticulous in their dynamic markings, they knew what they were doing... let's hear the music as they meant them to be heard.    This is one of the greatest Chopin recordings in the repertoire.

Certainly in the same company as Lennon and McCartney and equally as gifted. <br />    Buy this and all Steely Albums and enjoy.

0679416781|4.0|Michael Ondaatje's The English Patient is worth your time because it's beautiful. Ondaatje's writes like a Renaissance painter - eclectic voices like Herodotus, Kipling, even the Book of David in the Old Testament are artfully woven with entirely fictional narrators into this story of what comes after war within and without a human being. Four main characters cross paths after the end of World War II in an Italian Villa, their bodies and souls twisted and maimed from their experiences with violence, their stories brought to life by Ondaatje's quasi-mystical language. \\"They were,\\" as one of the characters states, \\"what had been left behind.\\" This eddy also collects David Caravaggio, the thumb less ex-thief, Kirphal Singh, a coldly analytical sapper, and the English Patient. The body of this last perhaps represents the souls of the others - charred and fragile, \\"like a burned animal\\", from conflagrations of a world beyond control. His constant companion, Herodotus' Histories, is a reliquary for scraps of memories, stories, poems, and Biblical scripture, pasted onto the book's pages so that the Histories in the end belongs more to English Patient than to Herodotus. The writing throughout The English Patient is intriguing and sometimes overpowering, like a strong perfume: traces of its tone curl into the corners of your mind and linger long after you've finished reading.  <br /> <br />

B0007GADZO|5.0|It took me a long time to realise the scope of this work. As several other reviewers have commented, this is very demanding music. But the effort of listening rewards. This is a real great rock album.  It's been a long journey for Steve Vai, starting out as a guitar wizard, and now composing and recording music beyond comprehension.  The centerpiece of this album is \\"Dying For Your Love\\" (Track 2). This piece is amazing. The bass booms hauntingly. The rhythm guitar does a clip-clip, which together with the bolero-like drums drives the piece. The lead guitar does stuff that sounds Turkish (or Lydian, as another reviewer has commented), but is unlike anything else that I've heard. Steve sings out his soul on this one. He makes interval leaps that are unusual and very expressive. In the refrain, an angelic choir emerges, rising to the heavens, in stark opposition to the bass and vocals. Excruciating - and beautiful.  Other pieces that I particulary enjoy are:   Freak Show Excess - Vai got the title from a derogatory review. Well, he turned it round and used it as an inspiration to make a fabulous piece. If that's what it means to be a freak, then I'll gladly join the show.   Building The Church is a spiritual powerhouse and a great warmup to Dying For Your Love.   When I hear Under It All, the word that comes to my mind is \\"montage\\". There are so many voices coming in and out. But he manages to keep the whole thing together. Quite an experience.   He plays beautifully on the 7th song Lotus Feet.  For Glorious he has invented a new instrument: electric cat.   Nobody has extended the range of musical expression within rock as has Steve Vai. You go through all the human emotions in turn: laughter, sorrow, amazement, awe, and simply grooving.   Two other great musicians have helped him put this masterpiece together. Billy Sheehan is Vai's true match on bass. Jeremy Colson does amazing stuff on his drums. The rhythm section is precise and punchy.   Giving this album five stars is an understatement.

The songs are written well, former Streets bassist Billy Greer (a Walsh sidekick to this day) slotted nicely into Dave Hope's bass position, and Richard Williams and Phil Ehart were back. A real treat was former Dixie Dregs and current Deep Purple virtuoso Steve Morse on guitar. <br /> <br />There were excellent songs like \\"Silhouettes In Disguise\\", \\"Dust In The Wind\\" soundalike \\"Taking In The View\\" and \\"Tomb 19\\". These were more akin to Streets than classic Kansas, however. On the negative side, \\"All I Wanted\\" and \\"Can't Cry Anymore\\" sounded too slickly tailor-made for mid-80's US radio play. Deduct half a star. <br /> <br />Mostly good to this point. But there was something missing... <br /> <br />NO VIOLIN. Robby Steinhardt was glaringly absent for both \\"Power\\" and \\"In The Spirit Of Things\\", though David Ragsdale came aboard for live dates and later recording and did an admirable job before Steinhardt rejoined in the late '90s. For a band whose distinctive sound depended so much on the violin/keyboard/guitar interplay, the lack of violin left a definite void. Deduct another half-star. <br /> <br />Don't let that stop you from buying this, though. As I've said, the songs are mostly very good, and without the tension between Walsh and Kerry Livgren, the sound is quite cohesive. <br /> <br />I've seen the band live three times since this reformation, and they've never disappointed. These songs sound even better live than in the studio, as later live discs will attest.

He is a big ATDI fan, and I've never really been that fond of them (even now I only still mildly like them).  But as soon as Deloused started, I knew that I was being introduced to something special.  I was captivated from beginning to end.  Over the course of the next year, I listened to that album relentlessly.  When I heard that they were set to release a new one, I was very excited.  Another friend of mine downloaded the early leak which was very oddly mixed and fairly low quality.  I listened to it for a while, and I kinda liked it, but at first I definately thought that it was a drop in quality after Deloused.  When the album came out in March, I bought it the first day it came out.  The improved mix and quality certainly helped, but still I was a little weary of it.  Then, all of a sudden, one day it clicked.  I was listening to it and loving the absolute crap out of it.  Now I think that it's even superior to Deloused.  This album certainly took a while to grow on me.  It requires the listener to listen to it from beginning to end without interuption or distraction.  With repeated listening, the songs (which at first seem like a big jumble of riffs) start to reveal their underlying structure and meaning.  Then the album as a whole starts to reveal its underlying struture and meaning.  The flow of the album is nothing short of perfect.  I too was not to fond of the long noisescapes at first, but now I see them as essential parts of the album.  Just as a (good) movie doesn't always have constant action and excitement, a good album needs to just cool down and let the listener relax for a few minutes.  Cassandra Gemini (probably the best song on the album, though I think it kinda sucks that they cut it up into eight parts) is just not the same if you don't hear the segue (or lack thereof) from Miranda into Cassandra.  When that awesome jam from the end of Cygnus... Vismund Cygnus gets reprised and its really quiet and you're lightly grooving on it and then, all of a sudden it jumps (might I say even \\"smashes\\") into Cassandra at an odd beat.  It totally catches the listener off guard.  Even after listening to the album so many times, I still can't pinpoint exactly when it's coming.  It still makes me jump a little.  I love when a piece of music can have such a primal effect on the listener.  This awesome effect is totally lost if you skip directly to Cassandra to avoid the slow and ambient Miranda.  The plot of the album is also incredibly moving.  Anybody interested should try to find a synopsis somewhere on the interent.  Even if it's not exactly what the band meant by it, it's still interesting to read what other people have interpreted about the lyrics.  Also, the albums title track (included only as the B-side to The Widow single) also explains a lot, as well as being an amazing track which anyone who loves this album should definately check out.  All in all, Mars Volta are a group of extremely talented musicians and composers who I feel will be looked upon as some of the greatest and (hopefully) most influential of all current rock acts.  Can't wait for their next one!!!

B00005JNJV|5.0|Having no idea what to expect from \\"Batman Begins\\", it was with some skepticism that I saw this film. If any other prequels were anything to go on, the expectation was not too high. \\"Batman Begins\\" removed all doubts and proved to be an excellent movie.<br /><br />The plot basically delves in detail into the formative life of Bruce Wayne and his development of the alter-ego that would be Batman. The movie covers this is a fair amount of detail, giving you insight as to how he met important people such as Gordon, and where he got his fighting abilities, his gadgets and even symbolic animal. As an underlying thread, Wayne's principles are also developed throughout the movie.<br /><br />Unlike one or two other superhero movies, \\"Batman Begins\\" keeps a fair amount of the action and pace present while it deals with the troubling issues that a budding crime-fighter of this kind faces. There is a fair balance between self-reflection and visual action that has been absent in other movies of this kind.<br /><br />Another aspect of the movie that is lacking in the earlier Batman movies is the brooding seriousness of it. Rather than an almost over-the-top, comic book feel, the movie presents a darkly serious characterisation. Even the villains share in this forboding seriousness, and lack some of the light exuberance of Jack Nicholson's Joker, or Tommy Lee Jones' Two Face. While neither good or bad, this does mark \\"Batman Begins\\" as different in an important way. For me, this was an excellent difference.<br /><br />All in all, I enjoyed this movie much more than the earlier movies from the Batman franchise. It looks very different from the other movies, for obvious reasons, and I feel that it adds a deeper element to the Batman saga on film. This is a great film, and really has a lot going for it.
B00000613T|4.0|Boulez's basic instinct with Mahler is to be accurate and restrained. One can't say he goes by the letter of the score, for Mahler frequently asks the music to be wild, anguished, impassioned, and desolate. This Mahler Ninth is never those things. The CSO is a brash Mahler orchestra, especially under Solti in their Seventies recordings, but Boulez the anti-Solti  has tamed them. The fortissimos here, though powerful, remain controlled, and almost the second they are over, Boulez pulls back on the tempo.<br /><br />His refusal to let the music off its leash drives some listeners crazy--I find his Sixth and Seventh Sym. much too slack. The Ninth holds up better to a calm hand and a clear eye. By concentrating on orchestral blend and diminishing the Dionysiac frenzy, Boulez comes up with a reading which at the very lest is beautiful (although I did find the louder music a bit shrill as recorded).<br /><br />Overall, Boulez takes 79 min., easily capable of fitting on a single CD. The final Adagio is probably your best touchstone. It flows at a moderate gait compared to Bernstein or Karajan: at 21 min. it falls well outside the usual range of 24-26 min. It is songful where others are sad or even desolate. The time boulez shaves off this movement goes into a slower than usual first movement.<br /><br />I can't carp about this Ninth, and I can't love it, either. On its own terms, Boulez's Mahler shouldn't be condemned as clinical or x-rayed. But you can't help noticing the restraint he shows throughout--luckily, he allows the great climaxes to be volcanic in their civilized way.<br /><br />P.S. 2013 - A recent listen makes me choose \\"soulless\\" as the best description. I would take away a star if I wrote the review today.

B000A7S4B0|1.0|This is not LEGALLY even a Compact Disc!  The BBC reports (Nov 4, 2005) that Philips, who defines standards for CDs, is very clear that copy protected \\"music delivery systems do not count as Compact Discs and cannot use the CD logo.\\"  In 2002, Klaus Petri (Philips rep) told Financial Times Deutschland that \\"those are silver discs with music data that resemble CDs, but aren't\\".<br /><br />Apparently this record label is a subsidiary of Sony because Tim Foreman, the bass player of Switchfoot, posted a work around for this disc's style of copy protection (also on Switchfoot's disc under duress) on the Sony music forum.  Naturally Sony deleted it.  Unfortunately, even with this workaround, the copy protection still gets installed on your computer.<br /><br />DO NOT ALLOW YOUR COMPUTER TO AUTORUN WHEN YOU PLAY THIS DISC.  Also, if you use a username that does not have administrator privileges on your computer the rootkit on the disc may not be able to be installed.  But your best bet is NOT to use this disc (or ANY copyprotected SONY disc) on your computer.<br /><br />This rootkit is the same type of software hackers illegally install on your computer for nefarious purposes and is illegal in some states and a number of nations.  It will run on your computer using up CPU power even if the disc is not playing.  There is no uninstall provided.  You are not warned that it will be installed. It is poorly written code and incompatible with some software, causing freezeups and bluescreens.  And if you try to remove it with a spyware tool your computer will all of a sudden not be able to 'find' your CD drive and it will be unusable. B00008PX8P|5.0|In the 1970's, Zeppelin listeners first became fans as a result of the breathtaking virtuosity and energy demonstrated in the studio albums that sent nearly all of them to #1. But, even more than the other great bands of the time,  we knew that somehow what was electric in the studio could become EXPLOSIVE if we could get the chance to hear it live. As a result, particularly after the repertoire from Physical Graffiti was added, tickets to Zeppelin concerts became the dream chased by millions;the legend culminated in the April 1977 concert at the Pontiac Silverdome, the first time that a musical act earned $1 million for a single performance.    The other part of the dream, of course, was the chance to own an album from one of those concerts. Not a nightmare exactly but not enough to wake us up was The Song Remains the Same. What I think made that unfulfilling were the LONG segments with stuff like \\"No Quarter\\" and \\"Moby Dick\\". The excitement from a live album is supposed to come from the whole band playing balls out, not one guy doing everything while all the others are smoking cigarettes.    Well, WAKE UP EVERYBODY! We finally have what we're waiting for.  This DVD is all live and is probably matched in sheer quantity only by the Springsteen 75-85 package. While the whole thing provides enormous entertainment value, the part that really immortalizes them is the Knebworth concert. That performance demonstrates their unique ability to produce 100% power with 0% noise; no matter how loud I play it, it always seems right.    If you like Zeppelin a little bit, this will make you like them a lot; if you like them a lot, you will think you've gone to heaven.

0743201140|4.0|This is a great compendium of 34 positive business-related talents... An online test analyzes your immediate inclinations (strongly agree, agree or neutral) on 180 questions. Your answers determine your generalized reactions in life.  A tendency to respond consistently in a certain way points toward your personal strengths (a euphemism here to mean your 'proclivities').  Your bottom ranked areas are called non-talents that will never exist and should not really be concentrated on.  This is the 'revolution' that is presented.<br /><br />Employees are to be hired for positions based on heavy-weighted attention to these talents (instead of the traditional weighting on experience and skills).  Managers are to manage each employee individually according to his/her specific tested talents.<br /><br />This book masks much of the precepts of this wild new theory by couching it throughout the book in traditional and conventional Harvard Business School type theory.  Solid advice is given on measuring employees performance objectively and through survey.  Weaknesses... should be addressed when they interfere with successful action (common sense).<br /><br />Too much direct association is made with talents, satisfaction, and willingness.  The book assumes these all go hand in hand... period.  It is hard-wired in our brains.  It doesn't ever address the fact that subject A's 10th place talent may be greater than subject B's 1st talent.  It doesn't take into account the breadth of one's various talents - only the top five.  Our hobbies that we love and enjoy... Are we all that talented in them?<br /><br />That said, this is a great tool to discover more about yourself and rend you from some of your possible self-delusions, realizing that it is OK to be strong in some areas, but not in 'every' area.  Maybe you will get a deeper insight into what you 'love' that will change your life.<br /><br />Too heavy on conclusions, too heavy a concentration only on strengths (subjective business proclivities) and an almost ambivalence concerning weaknesses, no sense of balance, playing loose with statistics but heavy with the lives affected... Albeit insightful and offers possibilites into the mitigation of the sometimes stressful business world on the human experience.  Quality and thought-provoking interview and six-month review questions.<br /><br />Four Starsence concerning weaknesses, no sense of balance, playing loose with statistics but heavy with the lives affected... Albeit insightful and offers possibilites into the mitigation of the sometimes stressful business world on the human experience.  Quality and thought-provoking interview and six-month review questions.    Four Stars

B00003OO3O|5.0|With the 1975 release of their 4th studio album, UFO finally hit their stride. To a great extent, it was also their high water mark. For the rest of their turbulent career, they would produce excellent albums, but none of them were as consistent or as focused as Force It. From the wailing sustain intro of Let It Roll to the album closer This Kid's, the band are firing on all cylinders. Heavier and much more aggressive than anything they'd ever recorded, it also shows the rapidly growing maturity of their writing skills. The key to the album is the sheer diversity of the material, which for the most part is hard rock, but covering the wide spectrum of that genre better than 99% of their peers. Force It is the one truly essential UFO album, although I would have to strongly recommend its predecessor, 1974's Phenomenon. It covers a much wider range of musical styles and is as close to Force It's equal as anything in their catalog. However, Force It edges it out for the top spot through sheer, balls out energy. After Force It, the rest of the Schenker era albums were very inconsistent, with top notch songs balanced out with equal numbers of average to filler quality material. For the beginning UFO fan, start with 1974's Phenomenon and buy them chronologically. If you just want one UFO album though, buy Force It. There are better known songs on 1977's Lights Out and 1978's Obsession, but those both suffer from some really weak songs. Force It is perfect from start to finish. Enjoy!

They have to find the treasure thus saving their town, all the while solving an age old local myth about a pirate captain named \\"One-Eyed\\" Willie and the disappearance of a man named Chester Copperpot and out running a family of criminals called the Fratellis. Aside from all the cussing and swearing, and one of the worst blue screen shots in motion picture history, This is a good side splitter for the whole family. 0679422714|4.0|Mao Zedong is still worshipped widely in China as the greatest leader of modern times, admired as a powerful ruler who stood up to Confucian tradition and foreign domination, and heralded as a champion of the poor farmers who remain the majority of the nation's 1.3 billion people. In the years since Mao's death in 1976, many Chinese and even some Westerners have clung to the notion that he was a noble patriot, an acceptable kind of tyrant. <br /> <br />In \\"Mao: The Unknown Story,\\" Jung Chang and Jon Halliday bring a wrecking ball to the towering myths surrounding Mao: that he was a voice for China's peasants, a military genius who masterminded the \\"Long March\\" of his Red Army to safety then led it in a war to repel Japan. Instead, Chang and Halliday portray Mao as a conniving, backstabbing, relentless schemer who was motivated solely by a will to power. It drips with tales of betrayal and treachery on an almost unimaginable scale. It also is a powerful narrative about China's sorrow, about a country wrecked by his malevolent methods.  <br /> <br />Chang is the author of \\"Wild Swans\\" (1991), a best-selling history of her family that also lyrically rendered China's beguiling culture and violent past. For \\"Mao,\\" Chang and her husband Halliday conducted a decade of exhaustive research, interviewing members of Mao's inner circle and hundreds of others. Mao emerges in these pages as a restless rebel in Hunan with a passion for literature who rose to power by outfoxing countless rivals to rule the Communist Party. He engaged in spectacular political fights, was responsible for a famine that killed more than 30 million and led a \\"Great Purge,\\" the authors' name for Mao's Cultural Revolution of the 1960s that devastated Chinese society. It's a book full of juicy characters. Lin Biao, who was so afraid of water that he didn't bathe, promoted Mao as a god and the Little Red Book of Mao quotations as a Bible, only to consider assassinating him and then, once discovered, was killed trying to escape to the Soviet Union. Chou En-lai, the polished diplomat who covered up decades of Mao's worst acts, was betrayed by Mao in the end. Jiang Qing, Mao's fourth wife and shrill attack dog, said at her trial, \\"Whoever Chairman Mao asked me to bite, I bit.\\"  <br />  <br />The myths that fall are numerous. One is that Mao's empathy with China's farmers put him at the helm of an agrarian-led revolution. In fact, the authors demonstrate, the \\"peasant uprisings\\" Mao claimed to have led were actually sophisticated power-grabs, in which he relied on bandits and used elaborate trickery to gain access to soldiers and power. Another is that the Red Army won the people's support by being upright, never looting or taxing the poor. The book shows persuasively that he stole aggressively from the rich, the poor and the in-between, and always insisted on luxuries for himself - eating delicacies, residing in palaces, bedding young women - even in the direst moments of war.  <br /> <br />Chang and Halliday portray the Long March as a series of make-shift steps, each intended to further Mao's own ascension, and they contend that his climactic battle at the Dadu River, intricately told in Edgar Snow's classic book \\"Red Star Over China,\\" was entirely made-up. They describe his treatment of his wives and children, whom he cast aside when they became inconventient, and of his enemies, whom he exiled, poisoned or executed. The authors use newly-available Soviet documents to that illuminate Mao's complex relationship with Stalin, how Mao begged for and depended on Stalin's aid in the 1940s, and may not have been able to defeat Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist army without it. They cite cable traffic between the two men to show how eagerly Mao welcomed the Korean War and sent millions of Chinese soldiers to death to serve his other purposes.  <br /> <br />In some places, Chung and Halliday go too far, effectively diluting the force of their argument: that Mao was a sophisticatedthug who bullied his way to the top and stopped at nothing to hold power. They allege that he was responsible for more than 70 million deaths, but their calculations are rife with guesses and worst-case suppositions. Many of their \\"revelations\\" have been published in bits and pieces in a recent gush of Chinese-language histories and memoirs. Some items are unreliable, others implausible.  <br /> <br />But the authors seem so set on demolishing Mao's reputation that they overreach. In one place, they imply that Mao's comments precipitated the erecting of the Berlin Wall. In another, they suggest that Mao caused Stalin's death because of a document found at Stalin's bedside about Tito, the troublesome Yugoslavian communist leader whom Stalin once compared to Mao - as if the mere thought of Mao were enough to trigger a stroke. The authors also have an annoying habit of portraying Mao's rivals as compassionate humanitarians, evidently to make Mao look more evil. Peng Dehuai, a war hero and defense minister purged by Mao, is described as someone who \\"cared about the poor and downtrodden.\\"  The authors' haphazard method of spelling Chinese names seems to reflect a disregard for accuracy. Most readers won't care, but anyone familiar with Chinese history will find it strange that Mao's third wife, He Zizhen, is referred to only by a nickname, Gui-yuan.  <br /> <br />In their efforts to demonize Mao, the authors fail to reflect on why Mao is still so admired in China today. Part of that phenomenon is an intense nostalgia that rests on Mao's perceived victories, his cleverness, his unpredictability. Even though information about Mao's sordid past is emerging, many Chinese insist on seeing him as the founding father of Communist China, as the embattled winner of its civil war and fight against Japan, the rough equivalent of George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Franklin Roosevelt wrapped into one. At the same time, Mao clearly stood for poverty and totalitarian control, nowcompletely discredited in China. Mao also went against many so Chinese ideals - respect for authority, concern for appearances - that he seems to represent everything that Chinese people ordinarily despise. In a repressive culture, it may be that the Chinese people yearn for a hero who rebels against all the traditional restrictions that they themselves willingly suffer. The authors do not mull over this possibility. Their epilogue is two sentences long, noting that Mao's portrait still hangs alone at the main gate of Tiananmen Square and that the Party \\"fiercely perpetuates the myth of Mao.\\" They miss the complexity and subtlety of today's China, and fail to explain why Mao still has such a hold on its people.
B000002U82|5.0|Dark Side Of The Moon is Pink Floyd's most popular recording, and for good reason. From start to finish, this album exhibits technical and instrumental excellence. Not since the Beatles' \\"Revolver\\" or the Beach Boys' \\"Pet Sounds\\" has one recording been so influential for musicians and studio engineers alike. It is also their first true concept album, centered around two of Roger Waters' favorite subjects - despair and insanity. The songs seamlessly tie together, giving the illusion of one magnum opus, which it is. Memorable cuts include 'Breathe', 'Time', 'Money', and 'Us And Them', though each one is tremendous in its own right. But unlike most of Pink Floyd's albums, the guitar doesn't play a big part, though it doesn't seem to take away from the experience one bit. Not only is this required for all Floyd fans, it is essential for all fans of rock 'n' roll...period. Dark Side Of The Moon didn't remain on Billboard's charts nearly 15 years by accident. This is one of rock's most triumphant moments, and it got me, like many other people, into the band. They are now my second favorite band (The Beatles being my absolute favorite), and \\"Piper at the Gates of Dawn\\" is my favorite PF album.<br /><br />So, do yourself a favor, and buy this album, or download it. Just get it. It's awesome. They DEFINITELY don't make music like this anymore, sadly.<br /><br />- Zack, 16 years old

This has a 17 minute version of \\"Echoes\\". The actual song (which can be found on the \\"Meddle\\" album) is 23 minutes long. Also, it only contains the first 7 parts of \\"Shine On You Crazy Diamond\\". This compilation also contains several \\"jumps\\" and \\"edits\\", so that the songs synch with one another, due to the fact that most of the songs are from concept albums. Casual fans may want to pick this up, but die hard Floyd fans will want to stick with the albums.

B00004BZ0N|5.0|London Calling is without question one of the most innovative and genre defining records of all time.  I'm 45 now and still have this in my CD player at least once a week.  That and Los Angeles by X have to be in every music fan's top 10.  Let's get back to London Calling..I was a sophmore at Chico State in CA and had just purchased the recently released album based on a review in Rolling Stone claiming this was a must have.  I had heard of The Clash and picked the record up at Sundance Records in downtown Chico.  Needless to say, I was amazed.  Just as I was amazed a year later when I heard \\"I Will Follow\\" off the debut album by a band called U2.  So after a month or so of pure Clash (including purchase of the first two lp's), I discover they are coming to the Bay Area and playing the Warfield Theater in SF.  I bought tickets and my girlfriend and I drove the three hours down to the Bay Area for the show.  The Clash came out dressed totally in black.  Black jeans, black short sleeve shirts, red scarves.  I forget which of these was the opening song but basically the first three were \\"London Calling\\", and then off the first record, \\"I'm So Bored w/the USA\\" and \\"Clash City Rockers\\".  I will never forget this, but the hair on the back of my neck was standing at attention.  I literally had chills running through me as the crowd up front in the pit were smashing each other, pogoing up and down, and hurling themselves at a snarling Joe Strummer.  Mick was staring down at his guitar and Paul was modeling for the crowd looking cooler than anyone in the whole theater.  I really don't remember the entire show or what the set list was but when we left the show, my girlfriend and I could literally not hear each other talking.  And I knew that I had witnessed something that could never be repeated.  I saw The Clash two or three times later in their brief career as a group, including the end when Strummer had a mohawk and \\"Rock the Casbah\\" was most everyone's first intro to thisgreat band.  If only they could have seen them back on the London Calling tour...

He has definitely raised the musical bar once again.<br /><br />\\"Fine Line\\" is of extraordinary caliber and \\"Jenny Wren\\" is noted for its beautiful acoustic and Paul's singing.  \\"English Tea\\" brings to mind the Beatle years; in listening to this, one can imagine Paul in 1967 singing this and it would be as wonderful and outstanding as it is as a recent work.  Indeed, this one does hearken back to Beatle days; one can indeed hear the unique influence as only Paul McCartney can provide.<br /><br />\\"Too Much Rain\\" and \\"Riding to Vanity Fair\\" are excellent songs that work as \\"counterpoint\\" or contradictory pieces.  The songs both show Paul at his cutting edge best.<br /><br />This is the kind of thing I hope we'll hear more of over time.  Paul McCartney has indeed shown a musical renaissance as well as his musical roots which are with the Beatles.  He deftly combines these and the result is nothing short of brilliant.  In effect, one can liken this to Gestalt - the sum being greater than the whole of its parts.  In this case, the parts being Paul's musical background with the Beatles and later with Wings and his more current solo works.  This is indeed a beautifully done Gestalt listening experience.<br /><br />No Beatle fan and/or Paul McCartney fan should be without this one.  The song writing is just spectactular.  You also get a DVD with a very nice doumentary about the creation of this CD.  You also get some animated footage as well.  Be sure to get this one and get ready for some high caliber music!
B00002MZ2C|5.0|Rage Against The Machine are seen as one of the pioneers of rap-metal, and they certainly do it right. I've always respected their intensity in their music, and although not all the time I agree with their messages, I thoroughly enjoy the music. <br /> <br />1.Testify 9/10...This used to be one of my favorites, but I unfortunately wore it out. Very fast paced and good. <br />2.Guerilla Radio 8.5/10...Another RATM classic, and probably their biggest hit. Alot like Testify, this is a fast paced rocker and I like the lyrics to this one. <br />3.Calm Like A Bomb 9.5/10...Best bass on the cd probably, this song is great. The verses are slow and rappy, while the chorus picks up and rocks. <br />4.Mic Check 8.5/10...This is an all out funk rap piece. But one can't argue with how cool Tom's guitar effect on this song sounds. <br />5.Sleep Now In The Fire 10/10...One of my favorite Rage songs of all time. Fast paced guitar intro with the thumping bass/snare drum combination. Very cool. <br />6.Born Of A Broken Man 10/10...Another one of my favorites. This song is very dark, and is probably the heaviest on the cd. The ending is very cool. <br />7.Born As Ghosts 8/10...Another darker weird song, the verses are rather forgettable while the chorus saves the song. <br />8.Maria 8/10...I've never really gotten into this song, it's not bad by any means, there's just not a component that grabs my attention. <br />9.Voice Of The Voiceless 8/10...As you can see, this is where the cd loses a bit of momentum, this track is a basic fast paced rocker, nothing too special. <br />10.New Millenium Homes 8/10...Alot like the previous, a bit boring still a good song. <br />11.Ashes In The Fall 9/10...Ah yes, now we're back with Ashes In The Fall. The beginning of this song sounds like the Halloween theme. This is another darker song, and the ending makes it. <br />12.War Within A Breath 9.5/10...What a way to end this cd. The beginning feels alot like Mic Check where you think it's going to beanother just rap song, when the heavy guitar kicks in and it rocks. The best part is without a doubt the bridge. <br /> <br />Rage give you a thrill every time you listen to them, and this being their most commercially accesible album, doesn't mean it's their best. I strongly recommend their selt-titled, Evil Empire, and Renegades.
B0007MWZEK|3.0|I bought one of these to do quick cleaning when I don't feel like pulling out the upright vac and fighting with the cord.  Works pretty much as advertised, although don't expect it to do more than light removal of loose dirt, crumbs, etc.  It's not going to get up pet fur or ground in dirt. Very light weight and easy to carry up and down the stairs.  Works much better on carpet than bare floors.  It will pick up on hard floors but takes a few passes to get all the dirt.  If you have carpeted stairs, you will find it handy to quickly clean up the steps.  The Swivel Sweeper is simply made and has a dirt tray on the bottom that is easy to snap out and dump.  The battery is easily removable and fits into a wall charger for recharge.  It seems like a well designed product, but I can't comment on reliability because I just purchased it. (The warranty is 90 days.) I would it have rated it at maybe four stars if it were a little less expensive, say about  $25.00. (I think the pretty hefty little rechargeable battery and wall charger is responsible for the higher cost).

B00003003R|4.0|For six years, between 1987 and 1993, Guns N' Roses ruled the rock world. It was six years of accusations of being racist, riots, tempter tantrums, swearing on live TV, urinating on planes, very public feuds with other bands, and of course, unbelievably great rock n' roll. From the days of when GN'R brought authenticity back to rock n' roll, when Bon Jovi were considered the premier rock band, to surviving the onslaught of grunge, GN'R were rock gods. In 1999, five years after the semi-original Guns N' Roses rocked an arena for the last time, the posthumous \\"Live Era '87-'93\\" hit the stores.<br /><br />While \\"Live Era\\" is quite good, it could have been better. Guns N' Roses was a great band, and put on an exciting live show, there's no denying that. \\"Live Era\\" is filled with classics, from each release, minus \\"The Spaghetti Incident\\" (1993). The band sounds great and performance on each track is top-notch. That said, \\"Live Era\\" is flawed in two ways-its chronology and production.<br /><br />As the back of the CD states, the songs on this CD were \\"recorded across the universe between 1987 and 1993.\\" For some bands, like Nirvana or Motley Crue, it wouldn't be any problem to compile a live album with songs from different years. With Guns N' Roses, however, it doesn't quite work. That's because the original Guns N' Roses went through four distinct phases:<br /><br />Phase I: 1986-1990: Axl Rose- vocals, Slash- lead guitar, Izzy Stradlin- rhythm guitar, Duff McKagan- Bass, Steven Adler- Drums. This lineup, generally regarded as the definitive one, recorded \\"Appetite for Destruction\\" (1987) and \\"GN'R Lies\\" (1998). This lineup was basically Aerosmith on speed, with an element of punk and the Rolling Stones.<br /><br />Phase II: 1991: Axl Rose- vocals, Slash- lead guitar, Izzy Stradlin- rhythm guitar, Duff McKagan- Bass, Matt Sorum- Drums, Dizzy Reed- Keyboards. The addition of the very proficient, yet slightly bombastic Matt Sorum and keyboard player Dizzy Reed made GN'R's sound slicker, less rough-around the edges. With this lineup, the band ventured out and experimented considerably, with the very ambitious epic \\"Use Your Illusion I\\" and \\"Use Your Illusion II\\" (1991).<br /><br />Phase III: 1992: Axl Rose- vocals, Slash- lead guitar, Gilby Clarke- rhythm guitar, Duff McKagan- Bass, Matt Sorum- Drums, Dizzy Reed- Keyboards. In addition, many backup musicians, such as female backup singers and a horn section were added. GN'R purists often regarded this period as the weakest link in the bands career. It is said that GN'R became very bloated during this leg of the tour and all the horns and added singers watered down the bands sound. I tend to disagree with that assessment. It was an interesting phase in the band's career and many of the songs, like \\"Move to the City\\" and \\"November Rain\\" sound enhanced with the extra musicians. Unfortunately, in 1992, when compared to the stripped down, unadulterated rock n' roll of Nirvana and Pearl Jam, Guns N' Roses huge backup entourage seemed excessive and bloated. Still, it was just an experimental phase, something that people often forget. As a live guitarist, Gilby Clarke outshined Stradlin.<br /><br />Phase IV: 1993: Axl Rose- vocals, Slash- lead guitar, Gilby Clarke- rhythm guitar, Duff McKagan- Bass, Matt Sorum- Drums, Dizzy Reed- Keyboards. All the excess musicians are gone. While not as raunchy as the early days, GN'R comes full circle and goes back to playing pure rock n' roll. Many of the songs are played even more stripped down, acoustically.<br /><br />The problem with \\"Live Era\\" is that there will be one song from the AFD/Lies era, then one song from the horn era, then back to the AFD/Lies era, and then will leap into '93, before going back to '91 and so on. While the songs are great, no doubt, the album overall is a little disjointed. It would have been better if disc 1 were strictly from the '87-'90 AFD/Lies era,, and disc II were from the experimental, '92 horn era.<br /><br />The other problem with \\"Live Era\\" is it sounds overproduced. The songs sound tampered with. There is some speculation that Axl Rose even re-recorded his vocals (although this is just speculation). They should have just left the songs as is, without trying to touch them up.<br /><br />While this list of criticisms seems long, it is not meant to imply that \\"Live Era\\" is a bad album. Indeed, the songs are still classics and if you are a fan of the band \\"Live Era\\" is well worth owning.rproduced. The songs sound tampered with. There is some speculation that Axl Rose even re-recorded his vocals (although this is just speculation). They should have just left the songs as is, without trying to touch them up.     While this list of criticisms seems long, it is not meant to imply that \\"Live Era\\" is a bad album. Indeed, the songs are still classics and if you are a fan of the band \\"Live Era\\" is well worth owning.

B000BW7QWW|5.0|Serenity's a rare movie. It gives popcorn-movie fun without insulting your intelligence. It also avoids the cynical game of \\"plot tweeking by the studio marketing department\\". The wisecracking crew of lost boys and girls trying to outmanuever the creepy-polite operative is entertaining, and good comedy. <br /> <br />The real magic is taking wild twists on familiar ground. Cliches are turned inside-out, but this cleverness never sterilizes its emotional core, the characters. Each one is presented with their failings in the foreground. The heros don't have infinite confidence and neat certainties. And that's the point of the story, trying to engineer people into an idea of perfection is a very bad thing. (German transcendentalists be warned: this is the opposition's arguement, with spaceships.) But noodling out underlying meanings isn't required, it's perfectly enjoyable at face value. <br /> <br />Serenity suffered from being released in the midst of the post summer movie hangover of late September, so it's box office gross doesn't reflect it's quality. This DVD's December release makes it a perfect antidote to the emotionally saccharine, Oscar-wannabe holiday fare.

B000AL730O|3.0|Starting a new world tour lends itself to a high profile opportunity to having your music presented to a great number of people, fans and critics alike. That being said however, with all the talk of this being his best solo work ever, one would believe all the hype and that something of the caliber of some of his greatest works would be presented on the new album and maybe for a lot of people this would be the first time in long time, the opportunity to solidly say \\"Paul is back\\". But, unfortunately that certainly doesn't happen here.  <br /> <br />But keep in mind the desire to say that comes more from his fans and critics, not from Paul. So it would be nice if the almost tearful references of a great talent finally making something worthy of his legacy to stop and see the album for what it is;  a snapshot of how Paul uses his talents and expresses himself at any given moment in time, critics & fans be damned! And if you're Paul McCartney you can say that. This seems to be Sir Pauls method and he's alluded to it himself in interviews. If another \\"Penny Lane\\" or \\"Maybe I'm Amazed\\" pops up then so be it. If not, oh well. <br /> <br />In all the reviews I've read, one word pops up in my mind; justification. Everyone seems to be justifying his work. And in Paul's case based on past (and in most cases WAY PAST accomplishments...)this is a man who certainly has nothing to prove although many of us, myself included that would like see him come up with one more blockbuster that would turn the world on it's head and if that was going to happen, this would have been it. But again, it hasn't and maybe wasn't supposed to happen. <br /> <br />The album itself has nice little gems, Jenny Wren (cousin to Blackbird and English Tea (can you say Penny Lane lite...?)but all in all it's McCartney doing what he's being doing for the past 25 years and that's trying to please himself.  <br /> <br />The saving grace of the album is Nigel Godrich who had the unenviable task of trying to rein in the McCartney Ego and force him to forego the banalities, corniness and incompleteness that have plagued his work for too long. It's not a job I would have wanted. So here it is, critics be damned.... <br /> <br />Here's the good....solid production, interesting melodies and chord structure, spiffy arrangements, complete ideas and the elusive quality of some of the tunes attaching themselves to your brain (takes a few listens though) <br /> <br />The not so good... Paul's voice is showing signs of age (although not live in concert interestingly enough) and if I had to fault someone for this it's Nigel in allowing Paul to be so \\"up front\\" and \\"dry\\" in the mix and not be able to shore up or color an obvious weakness. (maybe a battle lost by Nigel) <br /> <br />The album has a lack of energy probably due to it less than spontaneous approach. <br /> <br />Awful last song, Anyway, which is a blatant \\"nick\\" of Get Ready done by Jeff Beck and Rod Stewart.... unlistenable. I can't imagine no one not pointing that out to Sir Paul! (or again, maybe he did not listen or care) <br /> <br />So all in all, just buy the album, sit back and enjoy it. It's not his best by far but an interesting and engaging piece of work and a worthy but mild chapter in the McCartney scrapbook. Keep the pieces you like and ignore the ones you don't but be sure to dismiss them with a nod of the respect he deserves. After all, it's Paul. <br />

B000AADYRQ|2.0|I'm disappointed, but not as much as I would've been if they'd stuck with Barsuk records and still put \\"Plans\\" out. I was warned ahead of time, when they announced the switch of labels, that there was a 50/50 chance I wouldn't like the new stuff. Sure, it may be cliche to think that major label= crap, but it's usually true. A switch to a major label can't make a great band like Death Cab totally awful, and there's some good moments on \\"Plans\\", but there aren't enough, and I don't think that is so much the fault of Atlantic records as the \\"fault\\" of the band wanting to move into a more mainstream direction. In \\"Plans\\", it's pretty clear to discern two things: they're trying to recreate the popular songs from \\"Transatlanticism\\", which was already a more commercial album than they'd ever done before, and they're trying to borrow a lot from Gibbard's side project \\"The Postal Service\\", which has had much better commercial and radio success than any Death Cab record. I think it's clear to see that Death Cab want to broaden their fanbase, and it's the first thing I hear on \\"Plans\\". To be fair, it would have most likely happened regardless of what label they were on, but I'm sad that it did because Plans is the poorest release they've come out with, ever. The only good songs to me are \\"Summer Skin\\" and \\"Soul Meets Body\\", which Atlantic pays every station so much money to play HOURLY that I can't even stand the opening chords anymore- way overplayed. <br /> <br />I guess all in all, Death Cab has put out more great albums in a row than most bands do in their whole career, so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and wait for the next one. In the meantime, I won't be buying this one- I'm not paying 20 bucks to feed the greed of The Man. Giving money to Barsuk was my pleasure, giving 10 cents to Death Cab and the rest to Atlantic isn't my idea of a good investment.
